awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of High Performance Liquid Chromatograph Mass Spectrometer
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs. Professor Justin Miller-Schulze from California State Sacramento (University Enterprises Inc.) and colleagues Thomas Landerholm and Amelia Vankeuren have acquired a high pressure liquid chromatograph mass spectrometer (HPLC-MS.) In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and study small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components move into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and the ions' masses masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph separates mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. This acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research. It also provides training opportunities to many undergraduate students through a variety of programs such as Sacramento State's Sustainable Interdisciplinary Research to Inspire Undergraduate Success (SIRIUS) program, whose goal is to provide undergraduates with authentic research experiences. This program involves students from the Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Geology and Environmental Studies. It includes a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) centered on the American River ecosystem as a central theme.

The mass spectrometer enhances research and education at all levels. It especially benefits research efforts investigating sources of adverse surface water quality using chemicals of emerging concern. The mass spectrometer also aids in the determination of the fate and transport of groundwater contaminants in mixtures related to oil and gas production.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The funds awarded to California State University, Sacramento as part of the NSF award, "Acquisition of High Performance Liquid Chromatograph Mass Spectrometer" were used to purchase and install an Agilent Technologies High Performance Liquid Chromatograph-tandem Mass Spectrometer (HPLC-MS/MS) in Spring of 2018. This instrument is housed in the Department of Chemistry laboratories but is a resource for the entire campus. 


To date, the acquired instrument has been used for a variety of research activities that have both informed faculty research projects and provided training opportunities for California State University, Sacramento's diverse student body. To date, the acquired instrument has provided training opportunities for 14 research students, 7 of which were graduate students. This number continues to grow with each semester. The instrument has been a critical component of the master's theses of 5 of those graduate students and provided data for on- and off-campus presentations for both undergraduate and graduate students alike. In addition, the instrument has been used in upper-division analytical chemistry courses to provide additional training opportunities, and 8 additional undergraduate students were trained through this course. 


The research projects made possible by the HPLC-MS/MS instrument are varied and demonstrate the interdisciplinary nature of the need for the instrument. Results have been published in the peer-reviewed literature and more publications are imminent. Highlights of this variety of research projects are described below:

  • The synthesis of anti-HIV agents was informed by the HPLC-MS/MS instrument, this work was published in 2021.
  • The generation of toxic and carcinogenic constituents of wildfire smoke was investigated using the HPLC-MS/MS instrument, the results of this effort were submitted for publication in 2021.
  • Concentrations of conservative (persistent) tracers of wastewater, like sucralose and carbamazepine and non-conservative (degradable) tracers of wastewater, like caffeine and metformin, were measured using the HPLC-MS/MS and was the focus of a master's thesis and will be published in the coming year. 
  • The effect of endocrine disrupting chemicals, i.e., Bisphenol A and other Bisphenol analogues, on the neurology and motor function of the fruit fly, D. Melanogaster are being investigated as a proxy for impact on human brain development and function. The HPLC-MS/MS instrument is being used to quantify these bisphenols in larval tissue in an intradepartmental collaborative effort. 

The acquired instrumentation has advanced knowledge in multiple disciplines as described above. Specifically:

  • We have a better understanding of the relationships between CECs in poorly and treated municipal wastewater, and the relationship between these CECs and traditional water quality metrics like nutrients and bacteria
  • Data on the potential presence of harmful constituents (i.e., carcinogenic heterocyclic aromatic amines) of atmospheric particulate matter has been generated
  • The chemical synthesis of anti-HIV agents was informed
  • The content of endocrine disruptors such as bisphenols in the D. Melanogaster model organism is being assessed and will inform the behavioral and toxicological data generated in these assays. 

The instrument acquired through this MRI grant has also benefited society and advanced desired societal outcomes. As described above, 14 research students and an additional 8 undergraduate students that used the instrument in their upper division analytical chemistry course were trained in the theory and operation of this current, sophisticated piece of analytical instrumentation. As the student body of Sacramento State is diverse and enriched in underrepresented minorities, this means that groups with historically limited access to instrumentation and sophisticated training have improved access and opportunities due to this NSF-funded instrument acquisition.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/24/2021
Modified by: Justin P Miller-Schulze
